course_title: Special Topics: Literature: Histories of the Voice
class_notes:
"Histories of the Voice" Our voices are central to our existence: they allow us to communicate and to form communities, to express ourselves in story and song, to inquire and inform. But for being so intimate, our voices also remain strangely outside our conscious control: they break, they falter, they deceive and betray us. How does such a fraught and elusive phenomenon as the voice inform a culture? What can we learn from studying our voices through the lenses of literature and philosophy? How does our relationship to the voice manifest differently across time? These are the questions that will inform this course, which will challenge students to think critically about what the poet Kamau Brathwaite called a history of the voice. Beginning with its representations in myth and oral tradition, our course will examine how the voice has been variously used and understood in the histories of literature, philosophy, music, and media, as well as cultural practices like podcasting and ventriloquism.


Readings will include works by writers such as Plato, Ovid, Walter Ong, Jacques Derrida, Fred Moten, Adriana Cavarero, Kamau Brathwaite,
